tool.name: A.) MaAsLin3-Lite
tool.command:
Rscript /galaxy-central/tools/maaslin3_lite/maaslin3_lite.R --input $inp_data --normalize FALSE --class $input_class
#if $str($gchoice_sub_class.global_sub_class) == "1": --subclass $gchoice_sub_class.input_subclass #end if
#if $str($gchoice_subject_id.global_subject_id) == "1": --random_component $gchoice_subject_id.input_subject_id #end if
--alpha_threshold $alpha_threshold && cp output/lefse_style_results_abundance.res ${output1} && cp output/lefse_style_results_prevalence.res ${output2} && cp output/summary_plot.png ${output3} && cp output/significant_results.tsv ${output4} && zip -r Maaslin3_Results.zip output && cp Maaslin3_Results.zip ${output5} && rm -r output

param.name: global_sub_class
param.label: Display sub-class
param.help: Select if input file contains sub-class

param.name: global_subject_id
param.label: Display subject_id
param.help: Select if input file contains subject-id

data.name: output5
data.label: MaAsLin Output zip results - please download

tool.help:
.. _Maaslin3: https://github.com/biobakery/maaslin3/ .. _Sample_Input: https://github.com/biobakery/maaslin3_lite/blob/main/hmp_aerobiosis_small.txt
**What it does**
MaAsLin3 lite is an improved MaAsLin3_ interface to LDA Effect Size (LEfSe)
.. image:: https://github.com/biobakery/maaslin3_lite/blob/main/output/summary_plot.png?raw=true :height: 800 :width: 600
**Inputs** ==========
* Sample_Input_
The text tab-delimited input file consists of a list of numerical features, the class vector and optionally the subclass and subject vectors. The features can be read counts directly or abundance floating-point values more generally, and the first field is the name of the feature. Class, subclass and subject vectors have a name (the first field) and a list of non-numerical strings.
Although both column and row feature organization is accepted, given the high-dimensional nature of metagenomic data, the listing of the features in rows is preferred. A partial example of an input file follows (all values are separated by single-tab)::
bodysite mucosal mucosal mucosal mucosal mucosal non_mucosal non_mucosal non_mucosal non_mucosal non_mucosal subsite oral gut oral oral gut skin nasal skin ear nasal id 1023 1023 1672 1876 1672 159005010 1023 1023 1023 1672 Bacteria 0.99999 0.99999 0.999993 0.999989 0.999997 0.999927 0.999977 0.999987 0.999997 0.999993 Bacteria|Actinobacteria 0.311037 0.000864363 0.00446132 0.0312045 0.000773642 0.359354 0.761108 0.603002 0.95913 0.753688 Bacteria|Bacteroidetes 0.0689602 0.804293 0.00983343 0.0303561 0.859838 0.0195298 0.0212741 0.145729 0.0115617 0.0114511 Bacteria|Firmicutes 0.494223 0.173411 0.715345 0.813046 0.124552 0.177961 0.189178 0.188964 0.0226835 0.192665 Bacteria|Proteobacteria 0.0914284 0.0180378 0.265664 0.109549 0.00941215 0.430869 0.0225884 0.0532684 0.00512034 0.0365453 Bacteria|Firmicutes|Clostridia 0.090041 0.170246 0.00483188 0.0465328 0.122702 0.0402301 0.0460614 0.135201 0.0115835 0.0537381
In this case one may want to use bodysite as class, subsite as subclass and id as subject. Notice that the features have a hierarchical structure specified using the character \|.
